description.narrative:
The project also worked to increase positive changes of gender perception in the families and communities. As project report in February, 2016, 201 women became community leaders, women and men joined decision making in the communities increased from 56%to 64.86%, men reported to stop their wives from participating in public activities decreased from 31% to 27.03%, and women felt afraid of her husband decreased from 74% to 59.46%. The project is working with 57 couple of Gender Road Map families.
In this proposed action,the project will use the saving for change (SfC) and agriculture cooperative (AC) as platform to revolve their existed saving fund sources as inputs to start up their integrated farming system (IFS) in the families. The project also supports some starting up inputs to the poor families as its criteria selection. As to assure sustainable, the committees of SfCs and Agriculture Cooperatives will play important role to link the products produced by farmers to access to the market and aswell value chain. Cambodia Community Innovation Center (CCIC), Facebook, page, and youtube are also the tools used by them to market their products and do research.
Assure food security and increase incomes of the poor and poorest farmers especially women in the communities, the project forms them into groups of Women Led Agriculture Service (WLAS). They are well-trained on skill to apply the system of rice intensification (SRI), and vegetable/cash crop growing activities in order to sell services to other farmers to earn incomes. These activities also help topromote sustainable SRI and vegetable/cash crop application in time that is lacking of labor force in the communities. More than selling the agriculture services, they are also well-trained to apply the vegetable/cash crop growing, livestock, and food processing to increase incomes.
In continuing to help the small holder farmers, the project also collaborates with commune councilors, villagechiefs, and farmer promoters to extend the application of system of rice intensification (SRI) adapted to serious drought which occurred in the target areas since these couple years. We will use selective ways to achieve it such as SRI hand-planting by using ricestems, SRI hand-plating by using direct riceseeds, roller disk drum seeder, local drum seeder, and recently with Agri-smart machinery seeder. Niek Srer is also another tool that will be promoted among the target communities especially the chemical free SRI farmers who are willing to produce chemical free rice for selling. As increasing trust among target farmers, the field demos, SRI fields day, and direct coaching are also being used, and they are encouraged to share challenges, lesson learns, and experiences to their neighbors. More than SRI application, the farmers also train well, share some inputs to grow adaptive vegetable/cash crop in the rice fields before and after the rice cultivation, livestock especially chickens and black ducks, and off-farming to earn additional incomes.
In order to increase the positive changes of gender perception in the GRM families and communities, the project will work withfamilies who committed domestic violence by applying gender road map (GRM) as a tool. The selected couple will be invited to attendtraining on how to set up the GRM annual operation plan to change behavioral practices. The plan focuses on the change of gender practices in the families and promoting to apply the integrated farming system (IFS) in the families to increase incomes. They are closely coached every month and reflected their activities every three months. The internal/external study tours are also used as toolsto achieve the annual plan as well.

participating-org.narrative:
#Rachana#, in Khmer means to be creative and artistic. Rachana is a locally staffed and managed Cambodian NGO based in Koh Andeth District of Takeo Province. Rachana was established and officially recognized as a Cambodian NGO on September 13, 1994. It was formed in order to continue and expand the work of the US based Cambodian Humanitarian Foundation (CHF).
When Rachana took over the work of CHF on September 13, 1994, it formulated a two-year transitional plan to train local people to assume responsibilities for themanagement of the project. In July 1995, it set a child spacing community-based distribution (CBD) Component and Maternal and ChildHealth (MCH) program in October 1996. Funding from PACT/JSI/USAID was ceased in April 1, 1997. However, the Maternal and Child Health program was able to continue through the support from Terre des Hommes, Netherlands. In 1998, the HIV/AIDS prevention project wasalso supported by the Khmer HIV/AIDS NGO Alliance (KHANA). At the request of the Daunkeo Operational District Health Department, Rachana replicated its community based model and its experience in Sre Ronong, Prey Sloek, Khvao, Roneam, Thlork and Leay Bo Health Centers, Daunkeo Operational District, Takeo Province. The program had achieved significant results from its operations, meeting and exceeding project goals, objectives and targets. Through the technical support from Canadian Center for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI) in Cambodia, In 2003, Rachana established two more programs on: Firstly- HIV/AIDS Prevention and Livelihoods for Women and Vulnerable Communities in rural area of Cambodia with the donation of L#oeuvre Léger in 5 communes of Treang district, Takeo provice, and Secondly- Community Participation in the Development of Health Center and Health and Nutrition Promotion with the donation of Canadian Cooperation Office (CCO) in Health and Nutrition Initiatives Fund to the three health cent# Rachana provided the facilitation to the communities through the participatory approaches that made the communities creating their own fundraising activities for supports the running health centers; HCMC, VHSGs and local authorities. Communities have understanding about the causes and effects of Diarrhea, worms, Typhoid fever, dengue Hemorrhagic fever diseases and accessed the health center services. # Rachana promoted the eco-agricultural farming system SRI Model and Income generation activities by using different innovation techniques. These approaches helped poor farmers shiftedfrom the tradition cultivation to the SRI model. They have shared the lesson learned and experiences about the farming system and vegetable production to the neighbored families in the communities. # The Community based organizations (CBOs) gained the empowerment, competencies and ownership. The approaches were applied to farmer-based association, social equity fund, rice bank, credit and saving groups. Those CBOs were functioning, clear structures, rules and policies and specified roles/responsibilities. Community leaders were able to lead and managed the social and economic activities include; saving and credit loans, and animal banks, rice banks and health social funds. Rachana is provincially located and has strong connection to local communities in Takeo, understanding the key needs, livelihood, environment, and development issues. Rachana team are dedicated professional technicians and project managers, skilled in natural resource and environment management, disaster management planning, and livelihood development. The team works closely with local authorities and forms strong relationships in the delivery of the projects, understanding the importance of seeking collaborative and sustainable solutions. The team is focused on inclusive participation, including poor women, men and youth in the four project areas of works as stated above.
